title: Saudi Arabian couple 'poisoned child with dangerous amounts of unnecessary insulin'
text:
A Saudi Arabian couple 'poisoned a young child with insulin' while the youngster was being treated for feeding problems, a court heard today.

Mohammed Asiri, 38, and wife Amal Asiri, 29, allegedly administered the medication to the child at the Evelina Children's Hospital, which is part of Guy's and St Thomas' NHS Foundation Trust, in London.

The couple deny 'wilfully ill treating the child in a manner likely to cause unnecessary suffering' while Amal denies administering a poison or noxious substance which could endanger life between 13 February and 9 March last year.

The child had been flown over to England from overseas in a private air ambulance to be treated for ongoing feeding problems, the court heard.

Mohammed Asiri, (right) 38, and wife Amal Asiri, (left) 29, allegedly administered the medication to the child at the Evelina Children's Hospital in London

Doctors managed to provide food through a drip until the child reached a stable condition and was flown home on 6 September 2017.

But the child was returned to the Evelina Hospital on 13 February 2018.

Alarmed by the youngster's plummeting blood sugar levels, doctors discovered the cause to be insulin injections, despite the child not being diabetic or having any need for the drug, it was said.

Both defendants are Saudi Arabian nationals and the court heard their defence is being supported by the Saudi embassy.

The couple are not permanent residents of the UK but are currently living in a flat in Kensington while on bail.

Judge Mark Lucraft explained to jurors at the Old Bailey that the Asiris have decided not to attend their trial.

He said: 'Previously they both pleaded 'not guilty' and each had told their lawyers what their case is, and lawyers will be representing the defendants during the trial.'

Sarah Whitehouse QC prosecuting, said: 'On Tuesday 13th February 2018 the child was admitted to the Savannah ward at the Evelina Children's Hospital in London.

'They had arrived in London from abroad in a private air ambulance.

'Over the next four weeks the child was repeatedly injected with insulin.

'The child did not require it.

'The effect of the insulin was to reduce her blood sugar levels to dangerously low levels.

'If a person stops eating for any length of time their blood sugar levels become very low.'

The child was looked after at the Evelina Children's Hospital, which is part of Guy's and St Thomas' NHS Foundation Trust, in London (pictured)

Ms Whitehouse alleged that the couple 'had access to insulin, they knew how and when to use it, and they knew what its effects were.'

She said evidence ruled out a 'rogue nurse' behind the poisoning as different nurses were working rotational shifts on the ward.

She stressed the dangers posed to a person when their blood sugar levels nose dive.

The barrister said: 'This is not a case where a rogue nurse was harming a patient.

'The signs of low blood sugar levels initially might be physical signs such as dizziness, weakness, sweating and hand tremors.

'If the blood sugars fall further there might be a change in behaviour: drowsiness, confusion, disorientation and aggression.

'If left untreated the person may become unconscious or suffer fits.

'If really prolonged and severe then permanent brain damage or death can occur.'

Amal Asiri allegedly pestered staff to check the child's blood sugar levels after poisoning them which led doctors to discover the child was hypoglycaemic.

'Asiri seemed to know the child's blood sugar levels had dropped and one explanation for this is that she was causing it to happen by injecting,' Ms Whitehouse added.

The couple, of Kensington, both deny one charge of cruelty to a person under the age of 16 between 1 May 2017 and 9 March 2018.

Amal Asiri also denies one charge of administering a poison or noxious substance to a child.

The trial continues.
description: Mohammed Asiri, 38, and wife Amal Asiri, 29, allegedly administered the medication to the child at the Evelina Children's Hospital in London.
